div.head: Cairene Society
div.p: Some time has elapsed since Cairo was termed 'the Grave of the Soul,' and before attending the obsequies of our own morals, we wish to flute a wild carol. The division of upper Cairene society into hostile circles is a touching tribute to its own vitality, and day by day the lines of each become more clearly marked. That these circles are fully outlined

div.head: Cairene Society
div.p: is obvious. In many cases restless spirits may be seen who would intrude into an alien circle, if their own efforts could give them sufficient momentum. If it were ordained that these circles could be self-supporting, lighted with a kindled flame of brotherhood and Christian feel-ing, each might revolve in hostile ecstacy. But the demands of actual life are constantly bringing these circles into rude conflict, in which sanctimonious tact alone prevents a sharer shock. The construction of dinner parties is a severe trial of calculating powers, as the position of each entity must be established. When contamination and moral repining result from a confusion of circles, when the enemy of a circlr is this far outcast to all within in, surely the irony is grim. Many a tear has bedewed this fair city, many a bitter word has floated into the genial air, through a mistaken introduction and a momentary slip. 'Hinc illae lacrimae.'

The strain of the hidden warfare is intense. Is our natural intelligence so great that it can be appied undimished to these tortuous problems ? By all means let us cut ourselves off from inferior circles, but let there not be dissensions in the higher spheres; let us be rude to each in a cheerful and brotherly spirit, neither sparing not looking for mercy. Let us not twist our tongues and gibe unseen, but rather exchange grimaces before all men. Lus us all race and shriek together, when once admitted to these higher circles. Let us not cluck and chatter in chosen haunts, but rather flutter, however helplessly, along the high-ways of existance. It is not a question of frantic affections and wild enthusiasms but of rational disinterestedness and fellow-feeling. Our doors need not be open to all, but those who enter need not clothe themselves with smooth veneer and rigid rectitude of mein. Use the pitchfork only when nature is impossible. "Know thyself and thou thyself shalt know."

div.head: Turkish Reform and Finance
div.p: The Porte has just informed the Powers of Europe,through the medium of the Austrian and Russian Ambassadors, that the partial execution of the reforms demanded has caused a deficit in the finances of Macedonie. It, therefore, proposes to raise the Customs duties from eight to eleven per cent, and Austria and Russia have agreed to consent to this is the Porte will accept the scheme of financial reform which was put forward, and will employ the money as the Powers desire.If it is once realised in Europe that finance is the key of the whole Near Eastern Ques-tion it is possible that some advance may be made. It is the miserable state of the Otto-man treasury which has brough about the whole affair, and the extortions of the tax collector are the root of all evil and dis-content. The Governer of a province has to remit a certain sum to Constantinople every year, and also to pay his oficials and his soldiers, and,what is moe important to him, himself. He farms out the rvenues of his province to men who exact far more than they ought, and who make a very good thing out of it. The Vali Pasha sends the necessary amount to Constantinople, helps himself liberally, and assigns the rest to his officers and officials, the troops, as a rule, coming off with next to nothing. The conse-quence is that two parties are dissatisfied; the peasants, who are exorbitantly fleeced, and the petty officials and soldiers who cannot get their pay. If once the Turkish finances were, like the Egyptian, placed on a sound basis, all this discontent would dis-appear. But as this would run counter to the policy of Austria and Russia, the needed reform will never take place.

div.head:
The War
Japanese Repulsed
1,000 dead abandoned

div.p: General Kuropatkin telegraphs that in an attack made yesterday against the Russian centre on the River Sasiho (1), the Japanese were repulsed, abandoning a thousand dead.
(Havas.)
Kuropatkin says that on the 14th inst. a fierce Japanese attack on the centre of our positions on the river Fan-Ho was repulsed. The Japanese left 1,000 dead in front of our positions. (Reuter.)
Oyama's booty includes an immense train of carts extending for 12 miles laden with am­munition and stores, which the Russians were compelled to abandon 15 miles north of Mukden. (Reuter.)
The captured Attaches are to be sent to Japan. * (Reuter.)

It is stated that the Cruncil of War has decided to immediately raise a fresh army which will include two divisions each of the Infantry, Cavalry, anti Artillery belonging to the Guardi. Hitherto, the Guards have not been called out. In non-military circles, how­ever, it is believed mobilization, in view of the present internal condition of the country, is impossible. (Reuter)
The train service between Yingkow and Sinminting has been resumed, the Japanese agreeing to abide by the Chinese regulations.
( Rsutrr.)
Although only a postponement is at present announced, it is believed here that the loan has definitely fallen through. (Reuter. >

The refusal of the Paris banker* to sign the Russian loan contract is regarded as a strong factor in the direction of peace, because the refusal was directly due to the apparent deter­mination of the Tsar to persevere with the war, which the bankers cousider suicidal in tho present circumstances. (Reuter )
Three Japanese cruisers and ono collier an­chored outside the harbour limit this morning.
(Reuter.)
Tho peasants have pillaged the estates of the Tsar and other members of the Imperial family in the provinces of Orel and Chernigoff.
(Reuter.)
An explosion has taken place on the Opera- square. Numerous arrests were made. (H.)
It is understood that a strict. flsnsorsbip will shortly be re imposed on tho Press and tele grams for abroad. (Reuter ]

div.head: Abbassieh Astlum.—
div.p: Egypt's only lunatic asylum, the one at Abbassieh, is to be in­creased by the erection of three pavilion, and a director's house.

div.head: Fgyptian Estates, Limited.—
div.p: We hear that the subscription for shares in the Egyptian lisutes, Limited, has been covered ten times over.

div.head: Army of Occupation. —
div.p: Major-General J. R. Slade, C.B., having left Egypt on retire­ment, Brigadier-General G.M. Bullock, C.B., has assumed the officiating command of the British force in Egypt.

Suez Canal.—17 vessels passed through the Canal on the 13th inst., of which 8 were British, 4 German, 1 Turkish, 1 Austrian, 1 Dutch, 1 Italian, 1 Egyptian. The day's receipts amount­ed to lrs. 403,363.9<, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 4,571,670.07.,

div.head: St. Patrick's Day.—
div.p: On Friday next, the feast of St. Patrick, there will be solemn high mass and a disoourse in English at St. Joseph's Church, lsmailia, Cairo, at 10 a.m. English aud American residents and visitors are invited to kindly assist at the solemnity.

div.head: Agricultural Congress. —
div.p: The Egyptian Government has selecied Boghos Pasha N ubar aud Mr. Foaden to represent Egypt at the forthcoming opening meeting of the Interna­tional institute ol Agriculture, which is to be held at Rome in'May. This decision has been I approved by the Council of Ministers.

div.head: Cairo Scientific Society.—
div.p: A meeting of the society will be held at the School of Medidne, Kasr el Ainy, on Monday next, 20ih inst., at 4 o'clock. Captain H. G. Lyons will read a paper on ''The Rains of the N ile Basin," and Dr. W. H. Wilson will show a new form of Calorimeter.

div.head: Grand Hotel, Helouan.—
div.p: To-morrow, on the occasion ol the. Helouan races, the Bracale Orchestra will perfurm during luncheon at this hotel. Luucheon tickets (P.T. 20 each) are ox) sale at all the N ungovlch Hotels, as well as at the offices of the Anglo American Nile S.S. Co. and of the Hamburg-American Line (Staugeu). Tables lor lunch should be ordered betorehand oh application to Mana­ger, Grand Hotel, Helouan.

div.head: Tragedy at Cairo.—
div.p: A shocking tragedy occurred at Cairo on Tuesday. El Saiiid El Aly, a butcher of Clot Bey, owed his colleague Mustapha MustapUa P.T. 10, the balauoe of the cost of a donkey which he had purchased lrom him. * On Tuesday afternoon the creditor went to El-Aly aud asked for the money, but as the latter continued to make excuses without giving any satisfactory assurauces as to payment, Mustapha plunged a knifeiuto his debtor, who was wounded mortally.

div.head: Helouan Racks.—
div.p: There are prospects of excellent sport aud a crowded enclosure at the Helouan races to-morrow. As this is the last opportunity the public will have this season of witnessing the event, those who have not seen Helouan aud the beautiful view of the white I Pyramid plateau stretchiug from Ghizeh to Dasboor in front of the grandstand should not miss this unique opportunity of doing so under the most pleasaut oircu instances. The Egyptian Cavalry Band will play during lunoh at the Tewtik Palace Hotel, which adjoins the race­course, and on the race-course during the meeting.

div.head: Y. W. G. A.—
div.p: A special meeting was held at tho Y. W. C. A. rooms, Cairo, on the 13th I inst., being the occasion of the jubilee bf this association. The Very Rev. Dean Butcher, D. D., presided. Lady Coote, vice-president for Ireland, gave a brief sketch of the work of the association during the past 50 years in all parts of the world, the membership being now over one million. Miss Maclnnes, the acting president, read a long report of the Cairo branch. Sir Algernon Coote, Bart., also said a few words in support of the work of the association. The Rev. A. G. W. Saunders proposed a hearty vote of thanks to the speakers and the proceedings terminated with the benediction.

div.head: PERSONAL AND Social
div.p: H. H. the Maharajah of Khapurtala, family and suite have arrived in Cairo via Port Said, and are staying at the Ghezireh Palace.

The latest arrivals at Shepheard's Hotel include Comte '3. de Montebello and party, Baron S. de Condfi, Comtesse de Roydeville ano party, Duke and Duchess d'Airola, Baron von Koenig, Baron von Tiedemann-Seeheim and family, Mr. Pembroke Jones and party, Mr. and Mrs. M. Rothschild, Comte and Com­tesse de Gironde, Mrs. and the Misses Farish, Mr. and Mrs. F. Lee Gilbert, Baroness von Furatenwertb, Mrs. von Heydweiler, Mr. and Mrs. de Saint Girons, Comte and Comtesse Holnstein, Comte d'Ursel, General and Mrs. Waters and family, Mr. F. von Mattoni, Mr. and Mrs. E. A. 8omnierville, Mr. Leidell and party, Mr. G. de Serstevens, Prof. Dr. Heimburger, Prof. Dr. and Mrs. Fraenkel, Col John G. Kelley, etc.

div.head: P & O Company
div.p: We are desired to state that the P. & 0. * Company's maiD line steamers to Marseilles regularly leave Port Said at 5 p.m. every Monday after, the arrival of the II o'olock ( morning train from Cairo, and a steam tender awaits the train to oonvey passengers on board. '

div.head: Stranding of the "Cairo"
div.p: Serious Charges
Who is responsible?

The International Chamber of Navigation of Alexandria has addressed a strongly worded letter to Rear-Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield on the responsibility of the Ports and Light­houses Administration in regard to the strand­ing of the S.S. "Cairo." The Chamber declares that it appears that the pilotage service was guilty of negligence, and that the catastrophe shows that there is a complete lack of such precaution, as wonld at least have helped to miuimise the disaster.

The "Cairo" approached the Boghaz Pass at 7.15 p.m., and when it struok the captain made the usual signals of distress and sent off a boat for help at 9.15 p.m. The boat got to shore at 1 a.m. and the Alexandria agent of the Florio- Rnbattino Company, advised by telephone, went at once to the Port Police Office, where he was mforinqdhthat on seeing the signals a search was being made for the captain and crew oi toe "Teir el-Mina." But only at 5 am. was the "Teir el-Mina" ready to go ont and only at 6 a.m. did it get to toe "Cairo," so there was an interval of ten and a half honra from the time the signals of distress were made until toe tug came up to the vessel.
The statements made in the Chamber's letter are so grave that we will publish it in fall in our next issue.

div.head: Notes from Port Said
div.p: News of the Baltic Fleet
(From our Correspondent).
Port Said, Wednesday.

Commandant Sohwank, Russian Naval At tecbfi, and Mine Schwank arrived here at 1] o'clock last night from Cairo, and have thic evening left for Djibouti by the Message rief Maritimes boat. This visit of Commandant Schwank to Djibouti is connected with th< refusal of the German colliers to oontinut further with the Baltic Fleet, and he has hope* ot making fresh terms with them. He expect! to return in four or five weeks. The thirc squadron of the Baltic Fleet is expected hen about the middle of next week.
SPEECH BY "GENERAL" BOOTH.

"General" Booth, of the Salvation Army who arrived yesterday from Palestine, gave t most interesting address to a large and repre sentative gatheridfc at the Seamen's Rest Iasi nigHY. His discourse, which lasted over &r hour, consisted of a most graphic and impres sive review of his life's work. Mr. Cameron His Brittanic Majesty's Consul, gave tw< short addre-ses in support of the gTeat worl which the ' General" is carrying on.
Count Montebello afrived here from Pales tin§ yesterday and proceeded to Cairo by th( 6.45 p.m. train.
GENERAL SLADE'S DEPARTURE.

General Slade, who left Cairo at 11 a.m yesterday to embark on the Orient steamei "Ormuz" at lsmailia, continued his journey t< Port^Said by the evening train, in consequent of the "Ormuz" being delayed in the Canal oi account of tho strauding of a Danish boat. H< was met at the station by his Exoellency thi Governor, Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, Mr. Tamil Director of Customs, Mr. Watson, superinten dent ol the line, etc., and stayed last night a the Savoy Hotel Heembarkedon the "Ormuz1 at 4 o'clook this afternoon and the boat Bailee at 5 p.m.
Sir Thos. Lipton, from Ceylon, was also i passenger by the "Ormuz,"
ITAbUN GUNBOAT.
The Italian gunboat "Barbarigo" (Capt Adolpho Ferrari), 7 guns, 91 crew, fror Naples, arrived at Port Said this morning, an< will proceed to Massowah.
RUSSIAN TROOPS.

The Messageries steamers, "Himalaya" an< "Polynesien" brought, respectively, 679 an 264 Russian officers and soldiers from Shang hai who have been transhipped to the Russia steamers "Komiloff" aud "Tsar" for Odessi

div.head: Notes from Suez
div.p: Suez, Wednesday.
H.M.'s "Barfleur," after having coaled at Suez, tailed for Colombo it 6 o'clock this morning. \

The British India new tnrbine steamer "Lama" (Capt. Wadge) sailed from Suez for Bombay at 7 a.m. to day. She is the fourth B.I. turbine steamer that has passed through the Canal, destined for the company's mail service on toe Indian ooast. Her speed is 18.6 knots.

The Danish steamer "Excellence Plesca," which grounded in the Canal last Monday afternoon, is still fast in spite of toe efforts of tug "Titan" to puR her off. She has new com­menced to discharge cargo into lighters.

The Britiih steamer "Planet Venns" strand­ed at daybreak this day in the Suez roads, owing to the captain misunderstanding the position of the split bnoy. She is, however, expeoted ta_getr"cJfaTlHgh tide this evening.

div.head: Building Land for Sale
div.p: On the road to Guizeh. Price L.E. 4,000 Write: P.B., Poste REstante, Cairo

div.head: Cairo Libel Case
div.p: Congdon a Houghton

This morning, the oivil aotion brought by Mr. Congdon of Cairo qgainst Mr. Wm. Houghton on aocount of an alleged malicious and libellous artiole which appeared in the "Egyptian Graphio," cam* on for hearing before Mr. A. D. Alban at H.B.M.'s Consular Court. Maitre Cuppa appeared for the plaintiff, while Mr. Houghton oondneted his own de­fence. £500 damages were claimed.'

On the opening of the proceedings the judge stated that in all civil actions of £500 dama­ges or over, the provincial oourt was obliged to report the commencement of the aotion to the Supreme Court, which would decide whether it should hear the case itself or leave it to be heard by assessors at the provincial oourt.

The defendant then put in a complaint that oounsel for plaintiff bad visited a number of barristers and had shown them a scurrilous broadsheet, with a view to prevent them from giving him legal assistance. Counsel for the plaintiff stated he had only approached Mr. Rizzo, and in that case merely as a friend, to see if any honorable settlement oon Id be arrived at. Mr. Rizzo stated that Maitre Cuppa had seen him as a friend and had endeavoured to obtain an amicable settle­ment

The judge ruled that Maitre Cuppa had done nothing that oould in any way be regarded as unprofessional After some further protests by defendant, the judge asked him to state the main lines of his defenoe. Defendant asked the judge to dismiss the case on the ground that no demand had been made for an apology. Thi 8 was deqlined.

Defendant went on to object to the wording of the writ, whioh, he contended, did not obarge him with publishing the alleged libel, and did not state that the words were written of or oonoerning the plaintiff. He further con­tended that the oontext of the alleged libel which was not set out, substantially a'ters the nature of the words set forth in the statement of claim. In addition, he stated that the case should be barred as it had already been heard criminally. He quoted Mr. Blake Odgers' standard work (3rd edition) on the law of libel in support of this.
The last contention was disallowed.

Defendant then stated the remaining heads of his defence, saying that he relied on a notice dated 14th March, and sent tfi Mr. Congdon on that date, and dnly received by him. He denied the publication of the alleged libel and did not admit having written it. He further offered to show that it got into the paper by aocident, having been pnt on the deferred file, and that he had no control over its insertion, having already decided to leave the staff of the "Egyptian Graphio," and having already written a letter giving his resignation.
These being the main heads of Mr. Hough­ton's defenoe, the case was then adjourned pending the receipt of instructions from the Supreme Court at Constantinople, until Saturday, April 15.

At the close of the proceedings, defendant accused plaintiff and his counsel ot having sent a copy of the broad-sheet oomplained of to a prominent Government officiaL This was denied by Mr. Congdon and his counsel, and the accusation was withdrawn.

div.head: EGYPTS LAND. HUNGER
div.p: The rush for land in Egypt has attained enormous proportions, and the Government is overburdened with innumerable demands for concessions. The tit-bits, that these would-be concessionaires are nibbling at, are in the im­mediate neighbourhood of the great lakes. So persistent are these demands for conces­sions that the Ministry of Finance has issued the following notice:—

"In oonsequence of the decision arrived at by the Council of Ministers at its last meeting, the Ministry of Finance has decided to post­pone until further notice all sales of large areas oi uncultivated land. Sales of cultivated land, of isolated plots of uncultivated land of small extent, and of building land will be held from time to time as in the past."

The "Iiwa" states that the rush for land iD Mariout is so great that the cost of the "papier timbre" for addressing the demand for lands to the Government has bronght in of late L.E. 900 to the Government

div.head: LAND BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: This morning, there was considerable dis­turbance on the Alexandria Bourse owing , some brokers wishing to do some business in the shares of the Land Bank of Egypt A great manifestation took place against that bank, ^ and the committee of the stockbrokers was hooted and hissed at amidst great excite­ment
The members of the committee have sent in their resignations. An extraordinary gen- , oral meeting will be sommoned immediately.

div.head: QUARANTINE IN TURKEY.
div.p: f A telegram from Constantinople states that . the quarantine measures against Suez have been replaced by a medical examination, . disinfection, and destruction of rats on board. , This, however, does not apply to pilgrim ! vessels, which wiU oontinue to submit to the , measures prescribed on February 22.

div.head: The Assouan Reservoir
div.p: Height not to be raised
Important note by Sir W. Garstin.

The Council of Ministers adopted, at its I leering on Saturday, 11th instant, the! (inclusions shown in toe following note, and a appendices, submitted by Sir William larstin, Adviser to the Ministry of Publio forks:—
The question of raising the Assouan dam, and hereby increasing the volume of water stored i the reservoir, has, for some time, engaged be attention of the Irrigation Servioe.

In my recent report upon the Upper Nile lasin, (1) I discussed Sir William Willoocka's reposals regarding this point, and agreed with im in reoommending that the existing dam bonld be raised, so as to enable it to hold up rater to R.L 112, or six metres above the resent maximum level permitted in the re- srvoir. In the report in question, I gave my aasons for making this reoominendation, and eed not, consequently, recapitulate them ere. Before making this proposal I had itisfied myself, through the calculations y Mr. Webb and his engineers, that according > all accepted theories regarding dan construe- on, the footer of safety was sufficient to permit f the dam being raised to the height proposed, ithout risk of failure to the struoture.

I say "according to .all acoepted theories sgarding dam construction," as, at the time rhen I wrote my report, and Mr. Webb work- d ont his calculations, neither of us had been affirmed that any new theory regarding the tability of masonry dams had been put for­ward. We consequently applied, in this in-1 tanoe, that made use of by the International lommission of Engineers—appointed in 1894 J
o examine the Nile reservoir projects and]

rdinarily adopted in the case of dams, namely bal if the resultant of the forces lies well rithin the "middle third" of the base—so that, nder the assumed theory, no tension will ocur on the masonry—and if the weight of he dam is sufficient to guard against sliding, afoty will have been assured.
Several months after my report had been ublished, and Mr. Webb's calculations had een submitted to Sir Benjamin for
erification, we were informed that the lathematiciana had brought forward a new heory regarding the stresses upon masonry am8 and that the question had *wnniftfl & ew aspect

The whole matter is one of great imporance to every one in Egypt, and I have ome to the conclusion that the best plan o follow is to take the public into our oon-1 idenoe, so to speak, and to frankly state how he case stands.
Sir Benjamin Baker's report, attached to his note, folly explains his views regarding he state of the existing dam ftlMf tk^, [uestion of raising it.

I think, however, that I had better go , little further in my explanations than he ias done, and briefly relate the circumstances rhioh have impelled him to advise us to uspend the raising of the Assouan dam for he present

I will consequently go back to the beginning f the matter. The first intimation that we eceived of the existence of any new theories egarding the stability of masonry dam. wa8 .private letter from 8ir Benjamin Baker, lated October the 14th, 1904. espondence followed ; with the result that

rith the approval of the Egyptian Government -I requested Sir Benjamin Baker to come ont o E/ypt, and after a personal study of the iffect of two years' regulation on the Assouan lam—give ns the benefit of his experience, ind advise us as to what should be done. The ■eeult of hia examination is the report attached o my present note. Before I discuss it, I will mry briefly, attempt to give an idea of what he new theoiy regarding dams actually is.

It has been bronght forward by Mr. L. W. \tcherley, Demonstrator in applied mechanics so University CoUege, London, and by Mr. Karl Pearson, F.R.8., Professor of applied mathematics and mechanics of the same Institu­tion. (2)
The very high reputation attained by both these gentlemen as mathematicians is suffi- lient wairant that any theqry advanced by them must merit toe most serious attention.

Briefly stated, their theory is:—that the vertical sections of a dam, under water pres- mre, are more severely strained than the horizontal sections, and that, while a dam, designed under the rules hitherto applied,' may be safe as regards cracking horizontally, it may nevertheless be liable to do so verti- sally.

The calculations brought forward by Messrs. Atcherlejt and Pearson, to prove their theory, are extremely abstruse, and difficult to follow. Any one wishing to study them can do bo by obtaining the pamphlet in question.

The matter is now engaging the study and attention of the principal mathematicians and hydraulic engineers in England and in Franoe| and no doubt will give eanse to much discus­sion. Eventually, it is to be supposed that the specialists, in both countries, will arrive at a conclusion upon this most important theory which affects all existing dams, and which

div.head: no title
div.p: In my last year's report pjwti the Upper Nile, I outlined sundry projects' for study, by which this end might be attained—notably those for preventing the present wastage of water in the White Nile swamps. A special staff is now at work in the Sudan, studying these different projects. That some one or other of ifeem wil£4vfttuaUy be oarried out I feel confident, but both the studies and the execution of the works must, of necessity, re­quire a long period of time. If then we do not raise the Assouan dam, Egypt will have to wait for several years before any large inoreaso of summer water-supply oan be obtained. It ognapt be maintained that this will seriously affeot the prosperity of the country. It will merely retard its.present phenomenal rate of advanoe. In the meantime, there are many ways in which money oan be beneficially spent., besides the execution of large irrigation sche­mes. One of the most important is the com­pletion and perfecting of the railway system, so as to enable it to take full ad ?antaga»of the large inotaaae pf-produce that yrill, in the near future, hare to be transported.

Meanwhile, I would strongly urge that, for the present, sales of Government land, upon any large scale, should be altogether suspend­ed. In some three years' time, the remodelling werks in Middle Egypt will be completed. These works will result in a very large increase of the area under perennial irrigation, and there will be, practically, no surplus water available for land reclamation elsewhere.

No harm can be done by a postponement of the sale of land. The latter will not decrease in value, in fact, by waiting, it will probably rise in price. There is no urgent necessity for raisiog money by this means, and I can see no object in selling it before water is available for its irrigation. I am aware that many in- tendingpurchasers are wilting to make it a oondition of the sale, that, if the land be deli­vered to them now, they will make no. olaira for summer water, and will wait until the Government is io a position to give it to them.

I consider, however, that sales, under such conditions, should not beenoouraged. It can­not be pretended that they are to the advan­tage of the Government—-they must necessa­rily introduce an element of speculation into the bargain—and they will largely inorease the difficulties of the Irrigation Service.

In the Sudan, the same difficulties, as regards irrigation, will be experienced as in Egypt. No summer water oan be given to that country beyond the quantity, agreed upon by the authorities concerned, which pan be spared from Egypt. I am not talking here of lands lying within the rainy zone, where the periods of cultivation are different from those in Egypt, and where irrigation will not interfere with the water supply of the latter country.

As it is necessary to consider the question in all its aspects, I am of opinion that it will be wise now to thoroughly study the cataracts of the Nile, from Wady Haifa to Shablnka, and investigate whether a suitable site for a second dam and reservoir can be fonud in that region, by which means the extra amount of water required could be sfaftsd) supposing that the Assouan dam is not -to be raised. I recommend then that a pro­perly equipped party be despatched for this purpose, at the commencement ot next winter, -and that a detailed, levelled survey be made .of the oataraots. 8uch a work will take at least two yean, and possibly longer, and Should be oommenoed as soon ae possible.

As lot^ a* we considered it probable that the Assouan dam would be raised,there was no necessity for suoh a study, but now that there is a doubt of this, it beoomes, to my mind, a matter of urgency. Even after we ha vq, succeedad in'bringing down more water from the Upper Kile, we shall require a power of storing it, as <Baar as possible to the point where it will be required.

In the month of February, 1897, I made a summary examination of the cataracts between Wady Haifa and Hannek. My report was pub­lished-in |he shape ofa Blue Book,and I append an eutract from it, to the present note. (4)

I therein briefly discussed the different pos­sible sitee.There were objections to all of them, bnt'none of them were insurmountable, and it is almost certain that, somewhere between the aSpond and sixth oataraots, a suitable site— teith good possibilities of stora ge—will be found.

Sodh a work, constructed at any of these Sites, mast necessarily bea costly one, owing to =the remoteness of the region and the difficulties Connected with transport and labour. At-the same time; if we renounoe the projeot of rais­ing the dam at Assouan,there is no Other alter­native, and I consequently recommend that -these studies shall be put in hand at an early date.

In conclusion, although the delay is oerfainly disappointing, and although, if the Assouan dam be not raised, an economical and speedy means of increasing the water supply will be 'lost to Egypt, it oanndt be pretended that any ■serious obstacle will have been caused to the progress of the country. This has been, and continues to be, exceptionally rapid, aud a few years of comparatively slow development need hatfHy be taken into account. -

Egypt has got fall value for the money ex­pended upon the Assouan dam, and can, with­out any exceptional hardship, await the time When our studies shall show us which of the different projects is most advisable for execu­tion, as a means of still further increasing the cultivated area. (5)
Cairo, March the 4th, 1905.
W. E. Gamtih, Adviser to the Ministry of Public Works.

div.head: The Discovery at Theben
div.p: royal treasures of the 18th dynasty

Egypt lias ouce more surprised us with an archicological discovery of the first importance. Mr. Theodore M. Davis,whose discovery at the tombs of Thothmes IV. and Queen Hatshepsu at Thebes has already been described in the "Times" of Nov. 24, 1904, has been patiently pursuing his work of removing the mounds of debris in the Valley of the Tombs ol the Kings, nd has just made a discovery there such as not fallen to the lot ot any ex'plorer since .ngypt was opened to European research. He has tound a tomb which has never been visited or plundered since the age of the 18th Dynasty, and is still filled with the royal treasures of a time when Egypt was the mistress of the East and the source of its supply of gold.

On Sunday, February 12, ins workmen came ..cross the descending steps of a tomb, midway between the well-known sepulchres of Ramses IV. and Ramses XII. At ihe loot of the steps was a door cut in the rock and blocked with large stones. One or two of these having been removed,a boy was sent through the opening,and quickly emerged with a gaily-painted wand of office in, one hand and the yoke of a chariot, thickly plated with gold.ui theother.Theopeuiug was thereupon widened, and Mr. Davis himself stepped into the space beyond. There he found himself at the head of another flight of rock- cut steps, 20 in number, at the end of which was a second door, also blocked vith stones. Here, however, the outer face of the stones wiy still plastered with the mud on which were impressions of a Royal seal with rows ol fe' tered captiVes, while On one of the lower steps the two basins of coarse red ware were lying, <mt of which the mud plaster bad been taken. Higher up, on one of the steps, was a superb pectoral scarab, while on another step was a broken writing palette of alabaster. It was evident that the tomb had been eutered by robbers shortly after its construction; that, having been surprised in their work of plunder, they had fled hastily, leaving some of the objects they had stolen in the vestibule ; and that since that day it had never again been visited by man.

Professor Maspero, who happened to be at Luxor at the time, was at ouce communicated with, as well as other museum authorities, and, although the next day was the beginning of the Bairam .holidays, Mr. Davis arranged to have the work of opening the tomb carried on to its completion. It was accordingly opened the following (foy, in the presence of the Duke of Connaught and his suite, and a marvellous sight met the eyes of the fortunate discoverer. The tomb itself was not large, and its walL had never been smoothed or decorated, but it was filled from one end to the other with the Untouched and richest spoil of ancient Egypt. Mummy cases eucrusted with gold, huge alabaster vases of exquisite form, chairs and boxes brilliant with paint and gilding, even a pleasure chariot with its six-spoked wheels still covered fcy their wooden tires/ were lying piled one upon the other in bewildering pro fusion. It was some days belore the band ol exploj-ers qould even a>ce--taiii the full extent of the Jfeasures which the tomb contained.

The Sepulchral chamber is about 30 ft. long and 15 ft. wide, the height being no more than 8ft. On the left-hand side ol the eutrance were the two great wooden sarcophagi, painted black and gold, within which the mummy-cases of the occupants of the tomb, a man and woman, had been placed. The cases themselves were double, the outer case beiug completely plated with gold on the outside, except where the face of the mummy was realistically repre­sented, while the,inside was lined with silver. The second case was similarly plated with gold externally, but inside gold-leaf was used instead of silver. On one of the mummies a few objects were discovered such as were usually buried with the dead—a ' heart-scarab" made to imitate lapis-lazuli, another scarab of black-painted wood, a gilded "dad," the model of a hoe, and the like. Over a gilded mask, which must have belonged to one of the mum­mies, a veil of black muslin, or rather crape, was drawn. It is the first time that anything of the kind has been met with in Egypt.

The inscriptions on the cases, as well as on other objects found in the tomb, showed to whom it had belonged. It was the burial-place of Yua and Thua, the parents of the famous Queen Teie, the wife of Amon-hotep III. and the mother of the "heretic-King" Amon-hotep IV., of the 18th Dynasty. It was to her teach ing that the religious revolution attempted by her son seems to have been due, and since the disoovery of the cuneiform tablets of Tel el- Amarna, the Assyriologists have believed that she was of Mesopotamian descent This belief is confirmed by the inscriptions found in Mr. Davis's tomb. In these the itiunee of her parents are written in various ways, indicating that there was no fixed spelling of them, and that the Egyptians of the 18th Dynasty had the same difficulty in pronouncing and repro ducing foreign names as their descendants have to-day.

'No light, however, is thrown by the inscrip tions upon the parentage of either Yua or his wife. Thua is merely "the chantressof Amon," and it is clear that she and her husband were not of noble, much less of Royal, birth. They
post have lived, however, at Thebes with theii

daughter after her elevation to the position of "chief wife" of one of the greatest of the Egyp­tian Pharaohs, and here they died while Amon- hotep III. was still on the throne, and the wealth and power of Egypt were still un- ■ liniinished. Queen Teie, with all her influence, hud been unable to overcome the jealousy of the Egyptian aristocracy and include her parents in its ranks, but she revenged herself at their death by giving them the honors of a Royal funeral.

Beyond the coffins, at the western end of the tomb, the ground was covered with large sealed jars of wine or oil, and shell-like boxes of black-painted wood, each of which contained a piece of cooked meat, neatly wrapped in black muslin. Planted on the top of them was the chariot, broad enough to hold two parsons, richly painted and enorusted with gold. The leather-work belonging to it is still as fresh as when it was first made. Here also were found the four canopio jars of alabaster in which the entrails of the deceased were deposited. It would be difficult to match them as regards either size or fineness of workmanship. The heads which form their covers are in the best style of Egyptian art, and on being lifted were found to have under them a second set of heads, tli6 latter being of plaster coated with gold. At the eastern end of the tomb two other alabaster vases were discovered, each of them with handles and of exquisite workmanship.

This eastern end of the tomb contained a large number of small objects. There were among them seven pairs of sandals, most of them of papyrus, but one of them was of stamped yellow leather and another had been gilded. On the door were numberless boxes, each of them occupied by an "ushebti" figure of considerable size. Many of the "ushebtis" were of wodd, but some were of alabaster, and there were two of gold and two of silver. Here, too, was a second wand of office, together with vases and boxes of gaily-painted wood. Among the boxes perhaps the most interesting is a large "clothes chest" of palmwood and papyrus; it is lined inside with papyrus, has two fasten­ings of string, and contains a second case or shelf with papyrus daps. Apertures have been made in the sides_ for the sake of ventilation.

Some of the objects bore the names of Amonhotep III. and his Queen. This was the case, for instance, with a large vase of alabaster, as well as with a sort of box-stool, resplendent with gold and blue enamel, on the cover of which the Kiug is represented as sitting on the hieroglyphic of "gold." On another box, which is fashioned like a small table with legs, the Pharaoh is depicted in the same attitude, yellow paint taking the place of gold on a third box of smaller size. Among minor objects, one of the most beautiful is a Kohl-case of blue faience with the cartouches of the King. Near the latter the gilded handle of a mirror was picked up, together with a stone box, painted white and stuffed with cotton, the lid of which represented a recum­bent mummy with a winged soul on the breast. lu another part of the tomb were two large wigs. (

At its eastern extremity there was also a small armchair, the back of which is formed by the dgures of the god Bes and a monkey on either siue of him. Two other armchairs were discovered in the western portion of the tomb. The largest of these, with its seat of inter­laced palm-fibre, is profusely oruameuted with tigures in black and geld. At the back is a double representation of "the eldest daughter of the Kiug, Amon-sit" ; in each representa­tion she is seated on a throne, with a winged solar disk above, and a female slave bringing her the offeriug of a golden collar, while under each arm of the chair are three other female slaves holding up their offerings of rings of gold. An Ascription tells us that the gold had been brought from "the lands of the south." The legs of the chair are modelled after those of an ox, and above each of the front legs is a boss in the form of a human head. There is a second and rather smaller armchair which also belonged to Amon-sit, who was a daughter of Amon-hotep III. On the back of this the Princess is represented sitting with a cat under her chair and a female fan-bearer on either side, while under the arms of the chair is the figure of Bes between two monkeys. The picture of the Princess and her attendants is lined on either side by the so- called Greek tret, an interesting illustration of the intercourse that existed at the time be­tween Egypt and the iEgean. The two chairs of Amon-sit might have been regarded as pre sents from the Princess to the occupants of the tomb, were it not that three funeral biers, and not two ouly, have been found in it. This seems to indioate that the tomb ofYuaand Thus had already been the burial place of s member of the Royal family, and that when al the objects which now cover the floor can & removed and packed we may hope to discovei a "well" or ohamber in which the sarcophagui of its original occupant rests.

It will take some time, however, before th< work of thoroughly clearing the tomb out car be accomplished. Meanwhile it has revealer one striking fact—the ostentatious, not to saj vulgar, display of wealth which distinguish© Egyptian society in the later days of the 18tl Dynasty. We had learned from the Tel el Amarna tablets that Egypt was at the time the California of the civilised world—a lam where, as the foreign correspondents of thi

Pharaoh reiterate, "gold is as plentiful as dust," and in the profusion with which the precious metal has been lavished on the con- , tents ol the nrwiy-discovered tomb their words : receive a striking illustration. There was ! nothing, however mean or insignificant, which was not ii'cfu'.ly plated with the gold of the , desert mines. Even the Pharaoh is represent- | ed as seated upon the symbol of "gold,'' and the goddess Isis at the foot of Thua's coffin is pictured in the same position.

A pathetic relic of a dead world is a mat of palm fibre on which the figure of Osiris was delineated in soft mould. Seeds were then sown in the mould, and in the green grass which sprung from them after the tomb had been closed and sealed the Egyptians saw an image and earnest of the resurrection. A similar "bed of Osiris" had already been found in the tomb of Amon-hotep II. '

Although some of the individual objects discovered by Mr. Davis may be matched in previous finds, the discovery, as a whole, far surpasses any that has yet been made in Egypt, and is in the fact the most important ever made there, whether we regard the art and richness of the coffiu&^nd other sepulchral furniture, or the wealth of precious metal that has been lavished upon ' them. The chariot alone, for completeness and beauty of form, is unique. The discovery will not only increase our knowledge of the history and customs of the 18 th Dynasty of Egypt; it must also materially enlarge our conception of the artis­tic taste and skilful workmanship of the ancient "dwellers by the Nile." (From the

div.head: The Cotton Market
div.p: There is no improvement in the demand for Egyptian Spot Cotton, the amount of business , beiug very limited. Holders are anxious sellers, and quotations irregular @ 1/8 per tb decline for Brown, and unchanged rates for Upper Egypts.
In futures only a moderate business has been done; the following are the latest values: March 6.38 May 6.25 July 6.20 April 6.29 June6.22 Aug.6.19 Nov.6.12

American Futures.—The Market this week , has again been quiet with moderate fluctua­tions ; to-day's closing prices are however 8 @ 9 points higher than those of last Thursday. The offerings from America are very I limited*,and. the prospects of peace following, upon the terrific battle which is after many days* still proceeding in the Far East, has ; given a more hopeful tone to the Market; otherwise there is no new feature in the posi­tion and any .-peculative tendency is held in abeyance. We do not look ior more than frequent unimportant fluctuations in the im­mediate future.

div.head: The Cotton Industry
div.p: Strength continues the pervading feature of the Lancashire cotton iudustry. Employ­ers are literally coiuing money, especially in the weiving trade. A shed with 1,000 looms is making a profit of £6,000 a year —something never heard of before in the staple trade of the County Palatine. Opera­tives' wages in fcaanntacturing will come up for consideration in about three weeks, when it is thought anadvance will be promised to come into operation on July 1 next. The spinning trade in American yarns is very profitable, but the margin of gain is hardly so wide as at the beginning of the year. Still, the trade is aotive. Bolton yarns are not doing as well as Oldham numbers.

div.head: How to raise the price of cotton
div.p: An enterprising Yankee hailing from Texas recently made au offer (for a consideration presumably) to a New York firm to introduce that terrible pest the "boll weevil" amongst the cotton fields of the Southern States, in order to enhance the value of the remnants of the crop. The gentleman of entomological know­ledge, however, over-reached himself, and a result of his little move is that the Senate will be asked to introduce a bill prohibiting the introduction of insect pests under a penalty of five years' penal servitude and a fine of .I
